As Chair of the National Space Council, I am thrilled to announce the public opening of 
@NASA
's Earth Information Center (EIC).

Leveraging 60 years of space-based Earth observation, the EIC will use life-saving data to tackle the climate crisis at home.
https://gis.earthdata.nasa.gov/portal/apps/sites/#/earth-information-center…

"And when we do things that improve equity for the people who have it the worst, we are improving equity across the board." — S. J. Ralston, Mars research scientist, advocates for transgender and nonbinary people in the workplace. #PrideMonth https://nasa.gov/faces-of-nasa/sj-ralston…

The diversity of our NASA team is what brings different perspectives to our missions, and we celebrate and share their stories. To protect our people from personal attacks, we have decided to limit comments on this post.

You know about earthquakes, but what about moonquakes and marsquakes? We asked a NASA scientist about what otherworldly quakes can tell us: https://go.nasa.gov/3N68hP1

Oh, those summer nights! It's the #SummerSolstice, the longest day in the Northern Hemisphere—and the shortest in the Southern Hemisphere where winter starts.

Glance up tonight for a planetary cameo, with Mars and Venus just beside the Moon: https://go.nasa.gov/3CDqMaj

LIVE: Watch the ribbon-cutting for our new Earth Information Center at NASA Headquarters in Washington. The new tool will provide data to the public and decision makers to help adapt and respond to our changing planet: https://go.nasa.gov/eic
On Friday, June 23, @NASAAero leaders will give an update on the experimental X-57 all-electric aircraft. Tune in at 12pm ET (1600 UTC) for a media teleconference: https://go.nasa.gov/3NJOxE0

LIVE: Two cosmonauts are stepping outside the @Space_Station to install equipment and retrieve experiments. Today's spacewalk is scheduled to start around 10:20am ET (1420 UTC) and last up to seven hours—follow along at http://nasa.gov/live.

We've reaffirmed our shared commitment with the @USDA to benefit people everywhere. Our continued collaboration aims to address climate challenges and bolster plant-based research on the @Space_Station that could help improve food security on Earth. https://go.nasa.gov/3qXbYAN

How do places on Mars get their name? 

More than 2,000 locations on the Red Planet have official names, recognizing places on Earth, explorers, and even cartoon characters. Learn what inspires names for Martian hills, craters, and rocks: https://go.nasa.gov/3CmCYMm

Later this month, we're opening the Earth Information Center—a hybrid exhibit that offers an interactive look at our changing planet.

"'NASA for all.' That's something that I think is really important because we are the universe, right? We are made of star stuff."

Celebrate #Pride and learn how Rebecca Sirmons helps tell the story of the universe as NASA TV's executive producer: http://go.nasa.gov/3IVxzj7

#MissionToPsyche is on track for launch in October 2023!

An independent review board found JPL’s response to address factors contributing to the mission’s 2022 launch delay has been "world class."

LIVE: Tune in as we review next steps for the Psyche mission, set to launch no earlier than Oct. 2023. The spacecraft will study a metal-rich asteroid of the same name that may be the partial core of a building block of rocky planets in our solar system.

You're looking at 45,000+ galaxies.

This image was taken as part of the JWST Advanced Deep Extragalactic Survey (JADES) — a massive science program that’s revolutionizing what we know about galaxies in the early universe: https://go.nasa.gov/3CdLq0s
